channel.title: Final Year Research Log
channel.description: A scrapbook of research for William Park's final project

item.title: Habeats Landing Page Launched
item.description: I built a landing page for Habeats so it starts to gain some presence online. It needs a couple more updates to include a mailing list and…
item.content:encoded:
I built a landing page for Habeats so it starts to gain some presence online. It needs a couple more updates to include a mailing list and analytics tracking.

You can see it here: Habeats.net

item.title: Invision Prototype
item.description: I’ve developed an InVision prototype to browse through my screen designs. You can see it here: https://invis.io/QBPUOW87F3G
item.content:encoded:
I’ve developed an InVision prototype to browse through my screen designs.

You can see it here: https://invis.io/QBPUOW87F3G

item.title: Screen Designs
item.description: I’ve designed refined screens for Habeats. Some of what is below will be used and some won’t, as I’ve included my iterative process and…
item.content:encoded:
I’ve designed refined screens for Habeats. Some of what is below will be used and some won’t, as I’ve included my iterative process and style experiments.

Older designs / experiments

These were designs I did where I thought straying from the wireframes in some areas might lead to something interesting. It was helpful to do this just to get a feel for working with the colours and type.

Navigation Icon Experimentation

These designs were mainly focused on getting the navigation icons looking nice, although some other small bits did change too.

Induction and Day view

These designs are for the initial time a user opens the app. It’s somewhat of a guide through the progress of using the app while also being used as an opportunity to tell the user not take on too much. The final image is also how the day view will look

New Habit screens

These screens are the process of adding a new habit into the application.

Week View

These screens are designs of how I imagine the week screen to look and work.

Progress View

The progress view lets a user view their entire history with the application.

item.description: I’ve mapped out my application with low fidelity wireframes and a prototype. The follow images are easier to digest in the prototype form…
item.content:encoded:

However there is an extra image below which goes over the different task icon states.

Induction Flow

New Habit Flow

Today View

Week View

Week View - Task Icon States

Month View

item.title: Characters
item.description: I’ve created some characters which may or may not be used in-app. If they’re used I would only imagine they’re used very sparingly. I want…
item.content:encoded:
I’ve created some characters which may or may not be used in-app. If they’re used I would only imagine they’re used very sparingly.

I want to use them to add some personality into the app in key moments of the app, such as celebrating a milestone with an achievement. They would also be used in advertising images, store images, and the app icon.

item.title: Brand Colours
item.description: I already looked at some colours while I was designing my logo, but these are what I hope to use in the app. There’s a possibility that they…
item.content:encoded:
I already looked at some colours while I was designing my logo, but these are what I hope to use in the app. There’s a possibility that they could change but this is what I’m working with right now.

I’ve been thinking that in addition to having these set colours for the default theme, that I may include the ability to customise colours inside the app, maybe even as a reward.

item.title: Logo Generation
item.description: I started the process of building a logo for the project. I’m going to take you through the process of each iteration and what I was…
item.content:encoded:
I started the process of building a logo for the project. I’m going to take you through the process of each iteration and what I was thinking at each point.

This iteration was just to get something down on the page to work with. You can see that I already have the soft font in here. I had the dotted underline pattern to indicate “beats” to try convey the tagline without using the tagline. No colours or anything, just something straight to the page.

Experimenting with colour now, because I thought it was going to be important to visualise what I wanted from the logo, and it also worked way nicer with the type. I’ve got the tagline in now because the dots weren’t doing it for me.

Adding some contrast with colours between the tagline and wordmark as I thought it all blended together too much with the single colour scheme.

Changing up some colour here to experiment. At this point I was getting unsure about the previous playful colours. Pink and blue combined makes me think about genders instantly which wasn’t what I wanted.

At this point I started thinking that the logo was just very bland. I blame the boring purple-black for that now, but I thought it was the typeface in the wordmark, so I went a bit wild.

Maybe too wild, so I toned it down. But still not the style I was looking for. Started coming back to the realisation that I liked the soft font style more.

I went searching for a new typeface that had the softer edges but also had a bit more presence. I found Fredoka One which fit that bill perfectly. At this point I knew I was happy with the typefaces, and that it must be the colours that were off.

I felt like the previous purple-black colour was overpowering with the new thicker typeface. I brought it back to a playful pink colour, then moved the use of that purple-black down to the tagline. I feel like this hit the balance I was looking for.

item.title: Brand Name Generation - Habeats
item.description: I’ve been trying to come up with a name for my application, and I used a spider diagram to get a lot of words onto a page that I could mess…
item.content:encoded:
I’ve been trying to come up with a name for my application, and I used a spider diagram to get a lot of words onto a page that I could mess with and combine mentally.

I’ve ended up with the name Habeats. The reason I’ve chose this name is because a habit is repeating something over and over - repetition. With repetition you can get a beat. I’m aware this connection is a bit of a stretch so I’ll be using the tagline “Add Rhythm To Your Life” to help build the connection.

Habeats - Add Rhythm To Your Life

item.title: Typography
item.description: As previously mentioned in my moodboard post, I want the feel for the app to be soft and playful. I selected the Visby Round CF typeface…
item.content:encoded:
As previously mentioned in my moodboard post, I want the feel for the app to be soft and playful. I selected the Visby Round CF typeface because it achieves that well. It’s reasonably priced for commercial usage and it comes with a good variety of weights.

Type is one of the most common elements in most apps so I believe getting the feel that I wanted to achieve through the typeface is a huge win as it sets the tone for the rest of the application.

I’m using the minor third scale (measured with type-scale) with the app as it minifies the amount of scale difference between each level of the hierarchy.

item.title: Moodboard
item.description: I’ve developed a moodboard indicative of the style I want to go towards for my app. I want my app to be playful and soft, without coming…
item.content:encoded:
I’ve developed a moodboard indicative of the style I want to go towards for my app.

I want my app to be playful and soft, without coming across as childish. I want to use bright colours and a typeface that is easy to read, but has no harsh edges. I liked the scribble style of the image in the bottom right. I may like to use it for some UI elements, especially some of the icon parts.

item.title: Pricing
item.description: I’ve been giving some thought into the pricing structure I want to use for my app. I’ve chosen that I’d like to make the app cost a small…
item.content:encoded:
I’ve been giving some thought into the pricing structure I want to use for my app. I’ve chosen that I’d like to make the app cost a small price of £0.99.

A lot of the reason I’ve chose this price is because of how I personally use app stores, and from what I’ve read about them when searching for good apps to use myself. I do not mind paying a small amount of money for a refined app with a good experience and no advertisments. Also having to pay for an app has generally made me feel like the creator of that app has more confidence in what they’ve built, which has usually lead to a better experience.

Having it priced as such means I can give discounts at key moments, such as launch, to gain a user base. It means the product I’m delivering is something that I’m happy to have people installing on their phones without worrying advertisers are showing experience ruining content.

I could avoid all these things by making the app free, but I would like to continue supporting it in the future using the money earned.

I also considered making the app free with an in-app purchase to unlock a premium version which allows you to create more habits, but I think this goes against what I’m trying to achieve with my main gamification loop that I wrote about in the previous post.

item.title: Animation Style Experiment
item.description: I’ve been considering how I want my app to look. I love the idea of a soft-edged but soft “blobby” looking style, but in a minimal way. I…
item.content:encoded:
I’ve been considering how I want my app to look. I love the idea of a soft-edged but soft “blobby” looking style, but in a minimal way. I would like to enhance this style further with animation, so I gave a go at something using SVG filters and CSS.

Obviously, elements wouldn’t be dragged together but instead you can imagine items popping out of a button that all had this style.

One issue is I plan to make an app and I’m not sure how difficult or what technologies I would have available to me that would allow me to do something like this easily.

item.title: Gamification
item.description: I’ve been researching gamification, and using what I already know about Octalysis from my time working at “Yomo”. I plan to use gamification…
item.content:encoded:
I’ve been researching gamification, and using what I already know about Octalysis from my time working at “Yomo”.

I plan to use gamification in my app to enhance the the feeling of progress and motivation. I also want to use it as a form of slowly building the habit of using the app by keeping goals managable.

In my research for habits I found that one of the reasons a lot of people quit is because they take on too much. For example, someone starts a diet and remove too many calories from their allowance in order to lose weight faster, making the process too difficult and it results in them quitting. This is obviously not something I want to happen when people are using my app.

The Main Gamification Loop

I’ve came up with the idea of a main gamification loop that I want the user to experience. I want to combine the idea of streaks, along with the idea of unlocking additional “habit slots” to drive investment into the app, as well as a gradual increase in usage.

Terminology

Let me explain what I mean by “streak” and “habit slot”.

Streak: The number of days in a row where all habits have been completed.

Habit Slot: The number of habits the user is allowed to track in the app.

The Loop

  • User completes a month worth of streaks.
  • User has invested time and value into the app.
  • User unlocks a new habit slot.

  • User has ability to increase usage of the app.

    • User will hopefully create new managable habit to avoid losing existing value.
    • User should be finding the previously added habit(s) easier to maintain by this point.

Other Gamification

I would like to include some other forms of gamification to the app that work to give joy. A feature I know will be required, will be cheat days. I don’t want people to lose their streaks, or feel bad about having to miss a day. Instead a cheat day feature will allow people to skip a day with “permission”. I’d like to limit the amount of cheat days given by allowing the user to earn them as a regular reward.

I’d also like to create a score system. The score would work off the streak but could also be increased by forfeiting cheat days. The score would be reset when a streak ends, which should add more value to a streak, and a good target to hit if you fail your previous streak.

I’d also like to include badges, or achievements so there is some in-app acknowledgement about common milestones.

item.title: Competition
item.description: There are a few other apps I have took a look at because either I’m aware that they’ll be direct competition, or information from people…
item.content:encoded:
There are a few other apps I have took a look at because either I’m aware that they’ll be direct competition, or information from people have indicated they’ve solved some of their habit problems through certain apps.

Habitica - Gamify your life

Habitica aims to help you track the progress of your habits, and motivate you to improve your routine by using gamification as its main weapon. It tries its best to stray from being a “task management program” by disguising itself as a role-playing game.

Positives:

  • A completely new experience to tracking habits.
  • Detailed gamified experience.
  • Naturally attracts gamer audience looking for solution to habit tracking.
  • Always free.
  • Has a significant amount of downloads in both Apple and Play stores.

Negatives:

  • Looming subscription model for additional in-app rewards.
  • Gamification can be too much.
  • More time required to maintain using it.
  • Some reviews mentioning it’s buggy.

Verdict:

I’ve used this app myself in the past and I found that I got bored of the game, before I got bored of the habit tracking. The game is really the bulk of the experience with this app. While I do want to incorporate gamification into my app, I don’t want it to go anywhere near this extent. I believe habit tracking is something people don’t want to spend any more than a few seconds a day doing, otherwise you also run into an issue of having to motivate a user to form a habit of opening your habit tracker.

The subscription model is not a nice fit in my opinion, as it may make users feel like they’re not getting as much as they could be for their hard work. Not great when you’re looking to motivate.

It has gained a lot of success in being a wildly different solution to the problem, as this likely makes it attractive to media. (After I typed this, I checked the website again for a “featured on” section, and unsurprisingly, there is one).

Habit Bull

Habit bull is a fully featured habit tracker which aims to be as flexible as possible when it comes to breaking bad habits and building good habits.

Positives

  • Loads of features.
  • Straight to the point.
  • Well rated, lots of downloads.
  • Aimed at your average person.

Negatives

  • Very bland UI.
  • Maybe too many features (Built in motivational images?)

Verdict:

I’m not going to lie, this application is going to be the toughest competition I’ll go against. It has a lot going for it and the amount of features is intimidating. The only real weakness I see to the application is that it doesn’t provide much of an experience which makes me think could make the app less attractive to be launched daily.

In a way this app lets you set up your habit tracking to be very specific. There’s a lot of flexibility. This description gives a good example:

Very flexible goals like: number of times per day/week/month, only on certain days of the week etc. For example: 30 push ups every Mon-Fri, go to the gym 2 times per week, or even every 2 days

Maybe this is a weakness in that it’s too much? Without making it seem like I think like there’s no use to this kind of flexability, personally I just want to ask myself “have I succeeded x habit today? (yes / no)” and be done.

Other applications

I’ve done some lighter research in applications like “My Fitness Pal” and “Fitbit”, and while I will compete with them it’s hard to take a lot away from these applications. A lot of them allow you to track your stats far better, but in a way I believe this is beyond the scope of the problem I’m trying to solve. I think there’s enough room for my app idea to survive alongside these applications.

One interesting thing to consider is, however, some of these applications allow you to integrate with them. Perhaps it’s something I’d want to look at in the longer term.

item.title: User Personas
item.description: I’ve developed a couple of user personas. These are people who I expect would enjoy an app that lets them build good habits and get rid of…
item.content:encoded: I’ve developed a couple of user personas. These are people who I expect would enjoy an app that lets them build good habits and get rid of bad ones.

item.title: User Research
item.description: I’ve been digging into the data I got from my user surveys and also taking into account some information I’ve gathered about chatting to…
item.content:encoded:
I’ve been digging into the data I got from my user surveys and also taking into account some information I’ve gathered about chatting to people about this project.

I feel like most people I’ve talked to welcome the idea of an app to track your habits. During the chat people always mention that they have something they want to improve on in their life, or that it would be useful for them. These people have mostly been young adults aged around 25, but I’ve talked to people who are interested in the idea, who are as young as 19.

When talking to them the biggest concern for them, when they try to attempt to improve their routine without aid is that they lose motivation. One person said that this was because there’s no immediate reward, and a another said that it was because they find it hard to see any progress. This is great news, because these were the problems I initally seen myself, and these are the problems I’ll want to solve with the app.

Other people seen habits as a bad thing initially, and thought about issues like biting nails, or even smoking. When this was the case there was very different reasoning towards how a user would improve their routine. This was often because (with smoking being the most common bad habit) they were held back by addiction. In cases like nail biting they didn’t even realize they were doing it, which makes for a hard problem to solve.

While I do think my app could help to some extent by providing motivation to get out of a bad habit, or showing progress, I don’t want to focus on bad habits. Problems like addiction would, I believe, require a more focused solution aimed towards these issues.

Some people mentioned that they have found success using other apps such as “My Fitness Pal” which is geared towards weight loss and healthy eating - one of the most common “good habits” brought up. Because of this I need to consider compitition in areas like this too. One other person mentioned their fitbit tracks some of the stuff they would be interested in using this app for automatically, such as sleep habits.

item.title: User Surveys Launched
item.description: Today I launched a couple of online surveys in order to learn a few things about people habits, and their interest in the app. I asked about…
item.content:encoded:
Today I launched a couple of online surveys in order to learn a few things about people habits, and their interest in the app. I asked about peoples habits to see where people they struggle. This will be helpful if I decide to narrow the focus of the application. I had around 100 participents in total.

In this post, I’m going to talk about each survey, what I learned from the initial results, and what I could have done better.

Small-scale survey shared via social media

I launched a survey through a couple of my social media channels and also on Reddit to gather information.

The replies here were detailed and informative. However, it was tough to get people to do the survey. From the initial results, it looks like most people would be interested in an application that worked as a habit diary, that has extra features to help motivate them.

There’s a conflict about whether notifications would be a good thing, with some people finding them annoying, but others found them a helpful reminder.

One particularly interesting reply to the question about if they would use the app was:

“Depends. Normally I have trouble because using a habit tracker requires making another habit: using it.”

I hope this won’t be too much of an issue, as the research I’m doing to help hook people into keeping a habit by using the app should also apply to hook people into using the app as a habit. However, it makes researching this all the more important.

I’m not going to share this survey as I said in the survey that answers will not be shared, in hope for more truthful information.

Large-scale paid “worker” survey

I used one of Amazon’s services called mTurk to “purchase” survey results. For only a few pounds I was able to get 76 participents to do the survey. The reason I went for this option was because I wanted to see if anonymous responses would show different trends.

Answers here however were generally low-effort and only few went into detail. However, when they did there was sometimes more serious information to be found.

When asked what their positive habits were, people usually mentioned one of these 3 things:

  • Excercise
  • Time keeping
  • Healthy eating

When asked what their negative habits were, there was a wider range of replies:

  • Smoking
  • Procrastination
  • Negative self thinking
  • Drug usage
  • Gambling
  • Anger issues

There’s a couple of points from the negative data that I want to touch on. I hadn’t considered that I may be tackling the realm of addiction with this app. This is an area I should research in addition to habits, if it makes sense to do so.

When I broke the data to examine what age range I should aim for (by comparing age ranges, to app interest) I found that the range 25-34 wins by a long shot, with 41.67% of people saying they would try it. The next highest range was 18-24 at 19.44%. This lines up with what I generally expected.

If I were to do this again I would focus on “yes/no” that are picked up by comparision and analysis tools to help identify more patterns, as the low detail responses don’t give as much insight as I believe this approach would.

You can view the results from the large scale survey here: https://www.surveymonkey.com/results/SM-KP2QZ7R6L/

item.title: Research Plan
item.description: This is an outline for areas I plan to research, and how I plan to do the research. Gamification Gamification will be an important area to…
item.content:encoded:
This is an outline for areas I plan to research, and how I plan to do the research.

Gamification

Gamification will be an important area to research, as the app will rely on it to create hooks that keep people coming back to the app. I plan to research this by researching more into Ocyalysis (I already have some experience with it from work). I’m going to look into other apps that use gamification to hook people and find out if it could be applied to what I’m doing.

Motivation

Knowing what motivates people and how the brain works when it comes to getting motivated will be something that requires a lot of focus. I’m going to look at the psychology behind motivation, and research the two different types of motivation (intrinsic & extrinsic).

After learning the psychology, I’ll move onto research into how to motivate through the use of UI.

I would like to launch a survey online or talk to several people about what motivates them.

Habits

I’m going to look into the psychology behind what a habit really is. I’m going to look into how people have formed habits, good and bad, and how they’ve got out of them. I’m going to look at similar software like Habitica and see what they do to form habits. I’ve already bought Hooked by Nir Eyal and I’ll be reading it to see how I can get people hooked on my app. If I can get people hooked on my app, and my app gets them hooked to building habits, I’ll be doing well.

I’ll also try to get a survey launched online and talk to people about their habits and what motivates them to keep to them.

Target Audience

I’m going to look into who exactly would use an app like this. Should I be targeting a specific age group? When do people start getting concerned about their habits enough to want to correct them?

I’ll be putting together user personas to help me understand who my users would be. I’ll also analyise use cases for the app in doing this.

One-on-one “interviews” about this subject will be helpful as I can learn from people who would want to use this app, and from people who wouldn’t want to use the app.

I’ll also put together an online survey to narrow down who I should focus on.

Community

I want to put some focus on researching how to build a community. I personally think a strong way to motivate people will be to make them feel like they’re part of community. A community that people can share their successes with.

Being able to build community features will help the app greatly I believe.

item.title: The Project Outline
item.description: Project Overview Some people are creatures by habit, and some people struggle to keep habits. A habit, by definition, is something that you…
item.content:encoded:
Project Overview

Some people are creatures by habit, and some people struggle to keep habits. A habit, by definition, is something that you do often and regularly. This means forming a habit is no easy task without repeated focus. The problem is this repeated focus to build a habit can be hard to keep if you’re forgetful, busy, or even lazy.

This app will aim to use gamification hooks to pull people back to the repeated focus of creating their habit until the habit exists and fuels itself. Currently, my idea involves users earning virtual currency (but not crypto!) for keeping to their habits and spending that currency on rewards that users set up themselves. (But there’s no reason this couldn’t be expanded later to allow users to earn real rewards, like Sweatcoin). For example, if you kept to your diet habit 6 days a week, on the 7th day you can unlock a reward that allows you to treat yourself to a take-away. Of course, you could buy a take-away without that - but shame on that user!

Pros:

  • It will be interesting to apply gamification techniques to something that isn’t really a game.
  • It’s something that would help drive me personally. And I’m sure could help other people.
  • The potential to grow the idea into something like Sweatcoin, where you partner with businesses to offer rewards.
  • Potential for online interactivity (leaderboards, etc)

Cons:

  • Will depend heavily on gamification. If it’s applied wrong, the app will fail.
  • Has been done before. See Habitica, but I personally think it’s really heavy handed with turning habits into a game and I think there’s potential in simplifying this idea.
  • Useful on mobile, but only have resources to create on Android.

How might it be built?

This would work best if you can access the application at any time. So I believe native iOS & Android would be best. I would use React Native to build the UI, and Firebase to store user data. To aid with building a smooth experience, I might use some tools like React-Native-Interactable and Lottie.

A bonus that comes with using React Native is that although I only have resources to create an Android app right now, it’s easy to “port” a React Native project over to iOS.

Who will this be for?

People who struggle with building habits and need an extra push to stick to their newly created habit by giving out instant gratification. This could be people who are busy and need an extra reason to fit something into their day. It could be people who are forgetful about some habits, who need a gentle reminder from the app. Finally, it could be for people who are lazy who need something to motivate them toward forming a habit.

What’s the business model?

The likely business model would be to charge a small fee (£0.99-£2.99) for unlimited access to the application. There could also be a lite version that limits how many habits or rewards can be created with an in-app purchase to unlock the full version.

There’s potential to allow users to get the app in the form of a subscription if online features were added such as leaderboards. But I personally hate subscriptions.

There could also be potential in earning referral revenue from businesses who partner up to offer rewards.

item.title: Welcome
item.description: Hello there. This is a blog owned by William Park, a student of Interaction Design, taught at Belfast School of Art. What is this blog? This…
item.content:encoded:
Hello there. This is a blog owned by William Park, a student of Interaction Design, taught at Belfast School of Art.

What is this blog?

This blog is a small area of the internet for me to post my thoughts and research while creating my final project. It’s somewhat of a digital scrapbook. You could find anything here from ideas that I’ve had, to snippets from material I’ve been taking in as research.

The layout of this blog could change over time as I put more time into it, to keep the site’s content easy to digest.

What is my final project about?

Keeping in mind that this is the first post and the project idea can and mostly will change in ways, the general idea I’m working on is to build a native application that helps its users build and keep habits.

You can read more about the idea of the project in this post.
